III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The facility is located in a residential neighborhood in Warren, Michigan. The facility is
located in a 1 ½ story building. The first floor has two bedrooms, each containing three
beds. The rooms also contain closet and storage space for clothing and personal items.
The rooms are nicely decorated and clean. Also found on the first floor is a full
bathroom, a storage closet, a living room, kitchen, and a dining/recreation room. The
rooms are all clean, nicely decorated, and in good repair. Medications are stored
double locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Appropriate furniture and televisions are
located in the living and recreation rooms. The basement of the facility has storage
rooms, a staff office, and a garage. Resident records are kept locked in the staff office.
The second floor of the facility consists of a large room, storage closets and a
bathroom. This room is furnished with a daybed set up as a couch, chairs, and a desk.
The room will be used for therapy sessions, homework space, and if necessary, can
also be used as a bedroom, under the condition that it is not used for other purposes.
This room has a locked door which leads outside to stairs and an outside deck. It is
noted that a variance was requested and approved to R400.4640(1), regarding the
interior staircase leading from the first floor to the second floor. The rule states “In new
and converted facilities, stairs shall have treads of uniform width and risers of uniform
heights. Treads shall be not less than 9 ½ inches deep, exclusive of nosing, and risers
shall not be more than 7 ¾ inches in height.” This variance was necessary due to the
fact that the first four stairs on the interior staircase were 7 ½ inches deep, rather than
the required 9 ½ inches. The variance request was approved on 05/20/13. The facility
has outdoor space in a fenced-in backyard, however this area is not used at this time.
The plan is to install a privacy fence, at which time the outdoor space may be used by
residents with staff supervision. Surveillance cameras are located outside the facility,
as well as inside in common areas. The facility was found to be clean and in good
repair.
2

B. Program Description
The program is a crisis stabilization and step down program, for males and females,
ages 8-17 years of age. The facility is being licensed for a capacity of 6 residents. The
program will care for residents who have significant behavioral and mental health
issues, with a range of cognitive levels of functioning. Most residents who will be
referred to the facility will be placed there as an alternative to acute psychiatric
hospitalization placement, or as a step down from these types of placements. The
average length of stay will not extend beyond 14 days. During placement residents will
receive medical and dental care services, in addition to individual and group therapy,
and psychiatric/medication management services. The facility contracts with physicians
and a psychiatrist who come to the facility to care for residents. The facility also
employs a registered nurse who oversees medical and psychiatric medication needs.
The staff to resident ratio is 1:3 during both awake and sleeping hours. Line of sight
supervision is the expectation of staff for all residents at all times, aside from personal
care time. Education will be provided to residents through schoolwork provided by
parents/guardians, and through an on-line educational program. The facility is licensed
as a Children’s Therapeutic Group Home, and thus no form of seclusion or physical
restraint will be used or permitted. Facility staff will be trained in the use of Crisis
Prevention and Intervention (CPI), for de-escalation and safety purposes, however the
facility’s written policy indicates that no form of seclusion or physical management may
be used for any reason. Residents will assist staff with cooking meals and with laundry.
All of the facility’s policy and procedures were reviewed and approved by the consultant.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
There are no rule or statutory violations.
